@hudi-bot run azure

General rule of thumb is that, one should estimate the max time for the longest running query and set the cleaner configs accordingly. 
For instance, if tables gets a new commit every 5 mins and longest running query might take 30 mins to read the entire data. 
One should set the cleaner commits to > (30 mins) i.e. 6 or more commits to retain. 
may be adding some buffer, we can do 8. so, a file will not be touched for 40 mins by the cleaner from the time it was committed.

>Write a hudi table before this change with metadata table enabled

can we test the reverse. For e.g writers may be upgraded, while query engines may not be. So can we write hudi table with this change and then try to read it with older code?
Component data type is supported in release 0.11.0, you can try the master code then.

@wangxianghu 
thanks for review, I had fixed the problem you pointed out

@danny0405 ,the real problem is this operator just use the  the default parallelism of job instead of source parallelism. in some case, we will set parallelism for each operator include source operator. so this function can't chain the source operator, just because it always use the job default parallelism when source don't use the default parallelism of job.
if source don't use the default parallelism of job, so do this.

@danny0405 
in the real product scene，source operator don't use the default parallelism of job. for example,  kafka source will set the parallelism  mapping to partition num. in this case we can't chain the source operator with map function.that's why we need the config.

@danny0405 
in the real product scene，source operator don't use the default parallelism of job. for example,  kafka source will set the parallelism  mapping to partition num. in this case we can't chain the source operator with map function.that's why we need the config.
@wangxianghu THX for your review. I think it's a good advice for the description and the exception msg. Updated the code in the new commit. Could you help to review it again when you are free?

After some research, I found that by setting the below parameter to a lower value than the default value of 1024, the small file problem during the first load is fixed to an extent. Is this the recommended practice or should the small file size and the max file size limit parameters work for the first time load as well.

"hoodie.copyonwrite.record.size.estimate": "100"
@hudi-bot run azure

@nsivabalan @codope finally had the time to have a look.
I have the same problem in the spark-shell with both gist examples. We don't have a Hive server, only a metastore, so I used
```
option("hoodie.datasource.hive_sync.mode", "hms").
option("hoodie.datasource.hive_sync.jdbcurl", "thrift://localhost:9083").
```
(port forwarded our metastore running on k8s, used an azure path to write to).

I don't get any errors upon writing/syncing regardless the partition extractor.
(For the slash encoded day partition, I still had to replace the `hoodie.datasource.hive_sync.partition_fields` from the gist with a single value).

If I do something like `spark.sql("select * from hudi_mor_ts_ro").show`, I get in both cases the
```
22/03/16 18:09:30 ERROR Executor: Exception in task 0.0 in stage 40.0 (TID 61)1]
java.io.IOException: Required column is missing in data file. Col: [year]
```
error I described earlier (`Col: [year]` in case of the partition fields `year,month,day` for MultiPartKeysValue, or `Col: [date]` in case of a partition field `date` for SlashEncoded).

Let me know if I can try something else (maybe run metastore locally + write to local storage to see if that makes a difference)?
@nsivabalan apologies for the delayed response. let me check the comments.
This looks good, lets merge and then I will update the images quickly
@BenjMaq with` spark-submit` you can pass in hudi conf with `--hoodie-conf hoodie.datasource.write.recordkey.field=ID`.  That should also work with `spark-sql`.  Could you give it a try?
